comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: why there was an eviction?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Can you just imagine the tragedy that this was for some family?  Can you imagine the hurt and shame that was attached to having your few possessions thrown out onto the street to the laughs and catcalls of the local urchins?  When I was growing up this was still prevalent and those evicted had an uncertain future, ready accomodation was not always readily available, transporting your bits and bobs to a safe place was not easy.  Indeed the "handcart" nearby would probably be the only thing they could afford or obtain and there are some unforgiving hills in Waterford if your relatives lived in the wrong place. What a terrific and terrifying insight into social history?  Well done Carol, 1001 is a good start to the million!

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: Looking at all the women covering their heads ... it does feel like this picture taken here in the middle east and not in Ireland! Almost the same style with the black cloak (women in the past here did wear it in the same way too).

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tj_q8] Not sure your age profile TJ but in the 40's and 50's women in Ireland rarely left home with their heads uncovered.  They wore hats, scarves and shawls and the more genteel ones wore mantillas in church!  It would have been very unusual to see a married woman with her head uncovered and what they wore would almost define their station in life.  A hat meant middle-class, a scarf in between and the poorer and older women wore shawls, generally a sign of poverty in the cities at least!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This is not the right building, but it is a doorway on O'Connell Street very similar to the Auctioneers in this picture.

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] this is really interesting! Then, why some people I meet online think of us as retarded people coz women cover their heads ???

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tj_q8] coz they're retarded?  That scene has changed drastically since the 1960's when it was all change!  They generally covered their hair and not their faces and if you look at some of the older photographs on here you will see women with light veils over their faces when travelling.  It was a conventional thing rather than religious though a woman without a head covering in church would be really frowned upon!

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content: The photo reminds me of walking home from school near Cavan Town in about 1942/43 and seeing bits of furniture lying on the grass verge opposite a small one roomed cottage. I heard that the widow woman who lived in the cottage had been evicted for not paying the rent. The memory I always kept in my mind of the scene was that of a Sacred Heart picture lying on its side against a dismantled iron bedstead

comment.author: 16489083@N05
comment._content: Dear corncrake68 that truly is a very sad memory... so sorry... bless you!!!

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/] I think you are dead on with your streetview , I'm guessing the doorway was removed at some point in the past, I think there were probably two identical doors originally, however the building on the extreme right of the picture seems pretty much the same. Another clue is the plasterwork on the upper level of the building, it appears to be the same in the streetview and the photo.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: The auctioneer's premises is Haricot's Restaurant in O'Connell Street Waterford. The lane way with the people standing at it is called Gaffney's LAne. The building over the lane way has since been demolished and was replaced by an ESB building in the 1930s. That ESB building is now an amusement arcade.
